title: Shannon Capacity Converse (No Reliable Communication Above Capacity)
formal_statement: For a stationary memoryless channel with capacity C, no sequence of (n, R) block codes with rate R > C can achieve vanishing block error probability as n → ∞.
plain_language: If you try to send information faster than a channel’s Shannon capacity, there is no coding scheme that will make the error probability go to zero as messages get longer.
assumptions_scope: Discrete memoryless (or stationary memoryless) channel model
Capacity C defined in the Shannon sense (bits per channel use)
Reliability means block error probability tends to zero as blocklength n→∞
typical_traps: Confusing finite-blocklength performance with asymptotic reliability guarantees.
Assuming feedback or common randomness increases capacity for memoryless channels.
Equating zero-error capacity with Shannon capacity; they differ.

escape_hatches.description: Increase SNR, bandwidth, or change the channel to raise capacity C until the target rate R ≤ C.
examples: Use better physical layer to reduce noise
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Requires more physical resources or infrastructure.

escape_hatches.description: Permit non-vanishing error probability ε>0 (fixed) instead of requiring error→0.
examples: Operate at fixed block error 10⁻³ and use ARQ/outer codes to mitigate
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Not reliable in the asymptotic sense; overall system still experiences errors.

escape_hatches.description: Use list decoding or allow erasures to change the success criterion.
examples: List decoding with bounded list size >1
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Objective differs from unique, zero-error decoding; additional higher-layer costs.

test_or_check: Given measured SNR and bandwidth for an AWGN-like link, compute C = B log2(1+SNR). If a claim proposes reliable rate R > C without changing the channel (SNR/B), the claim conflicts with the converse theorem.
references: Shannon, C. E. (1948). A Mathematical Theory of Communication. Bell System Technical Journal.

references.citation: Cover, T. M., & Thomas, J. A. (2006). Elements of Information Theory (2nd ed.). Wiley.
references.relevance: Textbook treatment of channel capacity, converse and achievability.
